documentation:
CodeArtifact is a fully managed artifact repository compatible with language-native package managers and build tools such as npm, Apache Maven, pip, and dotnet. You can use CodeArtifact to share packages with development teams and pull packages. Packages can be pulled from both public and CodeArtifact repositories. You can also create an upstream relationship between a CodeArtifact repository and another repository, which effectively merges their contents from the point of view of a package manager client.

CodeArtifact Components

Use the information in this guide to help you work with the following CodeArtifact components:

  • Repository: A CodeArtifact repository contains a set of package versions, each of which maps to a set of assets, or files. Repositories are polyglot, so a single repository can contain packages of any supported type. Each repository exposes endpoints for fetching and publishing packages using tools like the npm CLI, the Maven CLI ( mvn ), Python CLIs ( pip and twine), and NuGet CLIs (nuget and dotnet).

  • Domain: Repositories are aggregated into a higher-level entity known as a domain. All package assets and metadata are stored in the domain, but are consumed through repositories. A given package asset, such as a Maven JAR file, is stored once per domain, no matter how many repositories it's present in. All of the assets and metadata in a domain are encrypted with the same customer master key (CMK) stored in Key Management Service (KMS).

    Each repository is a member of a single domain and can't be moved to a different domain.

    The domain allows organizational policy to be applied across multiple repositories, such as which accounts can access repositories in the domain, and which public repositories can be used as sources of packages.

    Although an organization can have multiple domains, we recommend a single production domain that contains all published artifacts so that teams can find and share packages across their organization.

  • Package: A package is a bundle of software and the metadata required to resolve dependencies and install the software. CodeArtifact supports npm, PyPI, Maven, and NuGet package formats.

    In CodeArtifact, a package consists of:

    • A name (for example, webpack is the name of a popular npm package)

    • An optional namespace (for example, @types in @types/node)

    • A set of versions (for example, 1.0.0, 1.0.1, 1.0.2, etc.)

    • Package-level metadata (for example, npm tags)

  • Package version: A version of a package, such as @types/node 12.6.9. The version number format and semantics vary for different package formats. For example, npm package versions must conform to the Semantic Versioning specification. In CodeArtifact, a package version consists of the version identifier, metadata at the package version level, and a set of assets.

  • Upstream repository: One repository is upstream of another when the package versions in it can be accessed from the repository endpoint of the downstream repository, effectively merging the contents of the two repositories from the point of view of a client. CodeArtifact allows creating an upstream relationship between two repositories.

  • Asset: An individual file stored in CodeArtifact associated with a package version, such as an npm .tgz file or Maven POM and JAR files.

CodeArtifact supports these operations:

  • AssociateExternalConnection: Adds an existing external connection to a repository.

  • CopyPackageVersions: Copies package versions from one repository to another repository in the same domain.

  • CreateDomain: Creates a domain

  • CreateRepository: Creates a CodeArtifact repository in a domain.

  • DeleteDomain: Deletes a domain. You cannot delete a domain that contains repositories.

  • DeleteDomainPermissionsPolicy: Deletes the resource policy that is set on a domain.

  • DeletePackageVersions: Deletes versions of a package. After a package has been deleted, it can be republished, but its assets and metadata cannot be restored because they have been permanently removed from storage.

  • DeleteRepository: Deletes a repository.

  • DeleteRepositoryPermissionsPolicy: Deletes the resource policy that is set on a repository.

  • DescribeDomain: Returns a DomainDescription object that contains information about the requested domain.

  • DescribePackage: Returns a PackageDescription object that contains details about a package.

  • DescribePackageVersion: Returns a PackageVersionDescription object that contains details about a package version.

  • DescribeRepository: Returns a RepositoryDescription object that contains detailed information about the requested repository.

  • DisposePackageVersions: Disposes versions of a package. A package version with the status Disposed cannot be restored because they have been permanently removed from storage.

  • DisassociateExternalConnection: Removes an existing external connection from a repository.

  • GetAuthorizationToken: Generates a temporary authorization token for accessing repositories in the domain. The token expires the authorization period has passed. The default authorization period is 12 hours and can be customized to any length with a maximum of 12 hours.

  • GetDomainPermissionsPolicy: Returns the policy of a resource that is attached to the specified domain.

  • GetPackageVersionAsset: Returns the contents of an asset that is in a package version.

  • GetPackageVersionReadme: Gets the readme file or descriptive text for a package version.

  • GetRepositoryEndpoint: Returns the endpoint of a repository for a specific package format. A repository has one endpoint for each package format:

    • maven

    • npm

    • nuget

    • pypi

  • GetRepositoryPermissionsPolicy: Returns the resource policy that is set on a repository.

  • ListDomains: Returns a list of DomainSummary objects. Each returned DomainSummary object contains information about a domain.

  • ListPackages: Lists the packages in a repository.

  • ListPackageVersionAssets: Lists the assets for a given package version.

  • ListPackageVersionDependencies: Returns a list of the direct dependencies for a package version.

  • ListPackageVersions: Returns a list of package versions for a specified package in a repository.

  • ListRepositories: Returns a list of repositories owned by the Amazon Web Services account that called this method.

  • ListRepositoriesInDomain: Returns a list of the repositories in a domain.

  • PutDomainPermissionsPolicy: Attaches a resource policy to a domain.

  • PutPackageOriginConfiguration: Sets the package origin configuration for a package, which determine how new versions of the package can be added to a specific repository.

  • PutRepositoryPermissionsPolicy: Sets the resource policy on a repository that specifies permissions to access it.

  • UpdatePackageVersionsStatus: Updates the status of one or more versions of a package.

  • UpdateRepository: Updates the properties of a repository.

AssociateExternalConnection.documentation:
Adds an existing external connection to a repository. One external connection is allowed per repository.

A repository can have one or more upstream repositories, or an external connection.
AssociateExternalConnection.name: AssociateExternalConnection

CopyPackageVersions.documentation:
Copies package versions from one repository to another repository in the same domain.

You must specify versions or versionRevisions. You cannot specify both.
CopyPackageVersions.name: CopyPackageVersions

CreateDomain.documentation:
Creates a domain. CodeArtifact domains make it easier to manage multiple repositories across an organization. You can use a domain to apply permissions across many repositories owned by different Amazon Web Services accounts. An asset is stored only once in a domain, even if it's in multiple repositories.

Although you can have multiple domains, we recommend a single production domain that contains all published artifacts so that your development teams can find and share packages. You can use a second pre-production domain to test changes to the production domain configuration.
CreateDomain.name: CreateDomain

DeleteDomain.documentation: Deletes a domain. You cannot delete a domain that contains repositories. If you want to delete a domain with repositories, first delete its repositories.
DeleteDomain.name: DeleteDomain

DeleteDomainPermissionsPolicy.documentation: Deletes the resource policy set on a domain.
DeleteDomainPermissionsPolicy.name: DeleteDomainPermissionsPolicy

DeletePackageVersions.documentation: Deletes one or more versions of a package. A deleted package version cannot be restored in your repository. If you want to remove a package version from your repository and be able to restore it later, set its status to Archived. Archived packages cannot be downloaded from a repository and don't show up with list package APIs (for example, ListackageVersions), but you can restore them using UpdatePackageVersionsStatus.
DeletePackageVersions.name: DeletePackageVersions

DeleteRepositoryPermissionsPolicy.documentation:
Deletes the resource policy that is set on a repository. After a resource policy is deleted, the permissions allowed and denied by the deleted policy are removed. The effect of deleting a resource policy might not be immediate.

Use DeleteRepositoryPermissionsPolicy with caution. After a policy is deleted, Amazon Web Services users, roles, and accounts lose permissions to perform the repository actions granted by the deleted policy.
DeleteRepositoryPermissionsPolicy.name: DeleteRepositoryPermissionsPolicy

DescribeDomain.documentation: Returns a DomainDescription object that contains information about the requested domain.
DescribeDomain.name: DescribeDomain

DescribePackage.documentation: Returns a PackageDescription object that contains information about the requested package.
DescribePackage.name: DescribePackage

DescribePackageVersion.documentation: Returns a PackageVersionDescription object that contains information about the requested package version.
DescribePackageVersion.name: DescribePackageVersion

DescribeRepository.documentation: Returns a RepositoryDescription object that contains detailed information about the requested repository.
DescribeRepository.name: DescribeRepository

DisassociateExternalConnection.documentation: Removes an existing external connection from a repository.
DisassociateExternalConnection.name: DisassociateExternalConnection

DisposePackageVersions.documentation:
Deletes the assets in package versions and sets the package versions' status to Disposed. A disposed package version cannot be restored in your repository because its assets are deleted.

To view all disposed package versions in a repository, use ListPackageVersions and set the status parameter to Disposed.

To view information about a disposed package version, use DescribePackageVersion.
DisposePackageVersions.name: DisposePackageVersions

GetAuthorizationToken.documentation:
Generates a temporary authorization token for accessing repositories in the domain. This API requires the codeartifact:GetAuthorizationToken and sts:GetServiceBearerToken permissions. For more information about authorization tokens, see CodeArtifact authentication and tokens.

CodeArtifact authorization tokens are valid for a period of 12 hours when created with the login command. You can call login periodically to refresh the token. When you create an authorization token with the GetAuthorizationToken API, you can set a custom authorization period, up to a maximum of 12 hours, with the durationSeconds parameter.

The authorization period begins after login or GetAuthorizationToken is called. If login or GetAuthorizationToken is called while assuming a role, the token lifetime is independent of the maximum session duration of the role. For example, if you call sts assume-role and specify a session duration of 15 minutes, then generate a CodeArtifact authorization token, the token will be valid for the full authorization period even though this is longer than the 15-minute session duration.

See Using IAM Roles for more information on controlling session duration.
GetAuthorizationToken.name: GetAuthorizationToken

GetDomainPermissionsPolicy.documentation:
Returns the resource policy attached to the specified domain.

The policy is a resource-based policy, not an identity-based policy. For more information, see Identity-based policies and resource-based policies in the IAM User Guide.
GetDomainPermissionsPolicy.name: GetDomainPermissionsPolicy

GetPackageVersionAsset.documentation: Returns an asset (or file) that is in a package. For example, for a Maven package version, use GetPackageVersionAsset to download a JAR file, a POM file, or any other assets in the package version.
GetPackageVersionAsset.name: GetPackageVersionAsset

GetPackageVersionReadme.documentation:
Gets the readme file or descriptive text for a package version. For packages that do not contain a readme file, CodeArtifact extracts a description from a metadata file. For example, from the <description> element in the pom.xml file of a Maven package.

The returned text might contain formatting. For example, it might contain formatting for Markdown or reStructuredText.
GetPackageVersionReadme.name: GetPackageVersionReadme

GetRepositoryEndpoint.documentation:
Returns the endpoint of a repository for a specific package format. A repository has one endpoint for each package format:

  • maven

  • npm

  • nuget

  • pypi
GetRepositoryEndpoint.name: GetRepositoryEndpoint

GetRepositoryPermissionsPolicy.documentation: Returns the resource policy that is set on a repository.
GetRepositoryPermissionsPolicy.name: GetRepositoryPermissionsPolicy

ListDomains.documentation: Returns a list of DomainSummary objects for all domains owned by the Amazon Web Services account that makes this call. Each returned DomainSummary object contains information about a domain.
ListDomains.name: ListDomains

ListPackageVersionAssets.documentation: Returns a list of AssetSummary objects for assets in a package version.
ListPackageVersionAssets.name: ListPackageVersionAssets

ListPackageVersionDependencies.documentation: Returns the direct dependencies for a package version. The dependencies are returned as PackageDependency objects. CodeArtifact extracts the dependencies for a package version from the metadata file for the package format (for example, the package.json file for npm packages and the pom.xml file for Maven). Any package version dependencies that are not listed in the configuration file are not returned.
ListPackageVersionDependencies.name: ListPackageVersionDependencies

ListPackageVersions.documentation: Returns a list of PackageVersionSummary objects for package versions in a repository that match the request parameters.
ListPackageVersions.name: ListPackageVersions

ListPackages.documentation: Returns a list of PackageSummary objects for packages in a repository that match the request parameters.
ListPackages.name: ListPackages

ListRepositories.documentation: Returns a list of RepositorySummary objects. Each RepositorySummary contains information about a repository in the specified Amazon Web Services account and that matches the input parameters.
ListRepositories.name: ListRepositories

ListRepositoriesInDomain.documentation: Returns a list of RepositorySummary objects. Each RepositorySummary contains information about a repository in the specified domain and that matches the input parameters.
ListRepositoriesInDomain.name: ListRepositoriesInDomain

ListTagsForResource.documentation: Gets information about Amazon Web Services tags for a specified Amazon Resource Name (ARN) in CodeArtifact.
ListTagsForResource.name: ListTagsForResource

PutDomainPermissionsPolicy.documentation:
Sets a resource policy on a domain that specifies permissions to access it.

When you call PutDomainPermissionsPolicy, the resource policy on the domain is ignored when evaluting permissions. This ensures that the owner of a domain cannot lock themselves out of the domain, which would prevent them from being able to update the resource policy.
PutDomainPermissionsPolicy.name: PutDomainPermissionsPolicy

PutPackageOriginConfiguration.documentation:
Sets the package origin configuration for a package.

The package origin configuration determines how new versions of a package can be added to a repository. You can allow or block direct publishing of new package versions, or ingestion and retaining of new package versions from an external connection or upstream source. For more information about package origin controls and configuration, see Editing package origin controls in the CodeArtifact User Guide.

PutPackageOriginConfiguration can be called on a package that doesn't yet exist in the repository. When called on a package that does not exist, a package is created in the repository with no versions and the requested restrictions are set on the package. This can be used to preemptively block ingesting or retaining any versions from external connections or upstream repositories, or to block publishing any versions of the package into the repository before connecting any package managers or publishers to the repository.
PutPackageOriginConfiguration.name: PutPackageOriginConfiguration

PutRepositoryPermissionsPolicy.documentation:
Sets the resource policy on a repository that specifies permissions to access it.

When you call PutRepositoryPermissionsPolicy, the resource policy on the repository is ignored when evaluting permissions. This ensures that the owner of a repository cannot lock themselves out of the repository, which would prevent them from being able to update the resource policy.
PutRepositoryPermissionsPolicy.name: PutRepositoryPermissionsPolicy

TagResource.documentation: Adds or updates tags for a resource in CodeArtifact.
TagResource.name: TagResource

UntagResource.documentation: Removes tags from a resource in CodeArtifact.
UntagResource.name: UntagResource

UpdatePackageVersionsStatus.documentation: Updates the status of one or more versions of a package. Using UpdatePackageVersionsStatus, you can update the status of package versions to Archived, Published, or Unlisted. To set the status of a package version to Disposed, use DisposePackageVersions.
UpdatePackageVersionsStatus.name: UpdatePackageVersionsStatus

UpdateRepository.documentation: Update the properties of a repository.
UpdateRepository.name: UpdateRepository

AccessDeniedException.documentation: The operation did not succeed because of an unauthorized access attempt.

AssetSummary.documentation: Contains details about a package version asset.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

externalConnection.documentation:
The name of the external connection to add to the repository. The following values are supported:

  • public:npmjs - for the npm public repository.

  • public:pypi - for the Python Package Index.

  • public:maven-central - for Maven Central.

  • public:maven-googleandroid - for the Google Android repository.

  • public:maven-gradleplugins - for the Gradle plugins repository.

  • public:maven-commonsware - for the CommonsWare Android repository.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository to which the external connection is added.
Information about the connected repository after processing the request.

ConflictException.documentation: The operation did not succeed because prerequisites are not met.

resourceType.documentation: The type of Amazon Web Services resource.

allowOverwrite.documentation: Set to true to overwrite a package version that already exists in the destination repository. If set to false and the package version already exists in the destination repository, the package version is returned in the failedVersions field of the response with an ALREADY_EXISTS error code.

destinationRepository.documentation: The name of the repository into which package versions are copied.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the source and destination repositories.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: The format of the package versions to be copied.

includeFromUpstream.documentation: Set to true to copy packages from repositories that are upstream from the source repository to the destination repository. The default setting is false. For more information, see Working with upstream repositories.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package versions to be copied. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId. The namespace is required when copying Maven package versions.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package that contains the versions to be copied.

sourceRepository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the package versions to be copied.

versionRevisions.documentation:
A list of key-value pairs. The keys are package versions and the values are package version revisions. A CopyPackageVersion operation succeeds if the specified versions in the source repository match the specified package version revision.

You must specify versions or versionRevisions. You cannot specify both.

versions.documentation:
The versions of the package to be copied.

You must specify versions or versionRevisions. You cannot specify both.

failedVersions.documentation:
A map of package versions that failed to copy and their error codes. The possible error codes are in the PackageVersionError data type. They are:

  • ALREADY_EXISTS

  • MISMATCHED_REVISION

  • MISMATCHED_STATUS

  • NOT_ALLOWED

  • NOT_FOUND

  • SKIPPED

successfulVersions.documentation: A list of the package versions that were successfully copied to your repository.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain to create. All domain names in an Amazon Web Services Region that are in the same Amazon Web Services account must be unique. The domain name is used as the prefix in DNS hostnames. Do not use sensitive information in a domain name because it is publicly discoverable.

encryptionKey.documentation:
The encryption key for the domain. This is used to encrypt content stored in a domain. An encryption key can be a key ID, a key Amazon Resource Name (ARN), a key alias, or a key alias ARN. To specify an encryptionKey, your IAM role must have kms:DescribeKey and kms:CreateGrant permissions on the encryption key that is used. For more information, see DescribeKey in the Key Management Service API Reference and Key Management Service API Permissions Reference in the Key Management Service Developer Guide.

CodeArtifact supports only symmetric CMKs. Do not associate an asymmetric CMK with your domain. For more information, see Using symmetric and asymmetric keys in the Key Management Service Developer Guide.

tags.documentation: One or more tag key-value pairs for the domain.

domain.documentation: Contains information about the created domain after processing the request.

description.documentation: A description of the created repository.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the created repository.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository to create.

tags.documentation: One or more tag key-value pairs for the repository.

upstreams.documentation: A list of upstream repositories to associate with the repository. The order of the upstream repositories in the list determines their priority order when CodeArtifact looks for a requested package version. For more information, see Working with upstream repositories.

repository.documentation: Information about the created repository after processing the request.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain associated with the resource policy to be deleted.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

policyRevision.documentation: The current revision of the resource policy to be deleted. This revision is used for optimistic locking, which prevents others from overwriting your changes to the domain's resource policy.

policy.documentation: Information about the deleted resource policy after processing the request.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain to delete.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

domain.documentation: Contains information about the deleted domain after processing the request.
The name of the domain that contains the package to delete.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

expectedStatus.documentation: The expected status of the package version to delete.

format.documentation: The format of the package versions to delete.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package versions to be deleted. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId. The namespace is required when deleting Maven package versions.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package with the versions to delete.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the package versions to delete.

versions.documentation: An array of strings that specify the versions of the package to delete.

failedVersions.documentation:
A PackageVersionError object that contains a map of errors codes for the deleted package that failed. The possible error codes are:

  • ALREADY_EXISTS

  • MISMATCHED_REVISION

  • MISMATCHED_STATUS

  • NOT_ALLOWED

  • NOT_FOUND

  • SKIPPED

successfulVersions.documentation: A list of the package versions that were successfully deleted. The status of every successful version will be Deleted.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository associated with the resource policy to be deleted.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

policyRevision.documentation: The revision of the repository's resource policy to be deleted. This revision is used for optimistic locking, which prevents others from accidentally overwriting your changes to the repository's resource policy.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that is associated with the resource policy to be deleted

policy.documentation: Information about the deleted policy after processing the request.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository to delete.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository to delete.
Information about the deleted repository after processing the request.

domain.documentation: A string that specifies the name of the requested domain.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the package.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of the requested package.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the requested package. The package component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package is its groupId. The namespace is required when requesting Maven packages.

  • The namespace of an npm package is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet packages do not contain a corresponding component, packages of those formats do not have a namespace.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the requested package.

package.documentation: A PackageDescription object that contains information about the requested package.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the package version.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of the requested package version.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the requested package version. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the requested package version.

packageVersion.documentation: A string that contains the package version (for example, 3.5.2).

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the package version.

packageVersion.documentation: A PackageVersionDescription object that contains information about the requested package version.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository to describe.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

repository.documentation: A string that specifies the name of the requested repository.
A RepositoryDescription object that contains the requested repository information.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository from which to remove the external repository.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

externalConnection.documentation: The name of the external connection to be removed from the repository.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository from which the external connection will be removed.
The repository associated with the removed external connection.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository you want to dispose.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

expectedStatus.documentation: The expected status of the package version to dispose.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of package versions you want to dispose.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package versions to be disposed. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package with the versions you want to dispose.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the package versions you want to dispose.

versionRevisions.documentation: The revisions of the package versions you want to dispose.

versions.documentation: The versions of the package you want to dispose.

failedVersions.documentation:
A PackageVersionError object that contains a map of errors codes for the disposed package versions that failed. The possible error codes are:

  • ALREADY_EXISTS

  • MISMATCHED_REVISION

  • MISMATCHED_STATUS

  • NOT_ALLOWED

  • NOT_FOUND

  • SKIPPED

successfulVersions.documentation: A list of the package versions that were successfully disposed.

DomainDescription.documentation: Information about a domain. A domain is a container for repositories. When you create a domain, it is empty until you add one or more repositories.

arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the domain.

assetSizeBytes.documentation: The total size of all assets in the domain.

createdTime.documentation: A timestamp that represents the date and time the domain was created.

encryptionKey.documentation: The ARN of an Key Management Service (KMS) key associated with a domain.

owner.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID that owns the domain.

repositoryCount.documentation: The number of repositories in the domain.

s3BucketArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon S3 bucket that is used to store package assets in the domain.

status.documentation: The current status of a domain.

DomainEntryPoint.documentation: Information about how a package originally entered the CodeArtifact domain. For packages published directly to CodeArtifact, the entry point is the repository it was published to. For packages ingested from an external repository, the entry point is the external connection that it was ingested from. An external connection is a CodeArtifact repository that is connected to an external repository such as the npm registry or NuGet gallery.

externalConnectionName.documentation: The name of the external connection that a package was ingested from.

repositoryName.documentation: The name of the repository that a package was originally published to.

DomainSummary.documentation: Information about a domain, including its name, Amazon Resource Name (ARN), and status. The ListDomains operation returns a list of DomainSummary objects.

createdTime.documentation: A timestamp that contains the date and time the domain was created.

encryptionKey.documentation: The key used to encrypt the domain.

owner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

status.documentation: A string that contains the status of the domain.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that is in scope for the generated authorization token.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

durationSeconds.documentation: The time, in seconds, that the generated authorization token is valid. Valid values are 0 and any number between 900 (15 minutes) and 43200 (12 hours). A value of 0 will set the expiration of the authorization token to the same expiration of the user's role's temporary credentials.

expiration.documentation: A timestamp that specifies the date and time the authorization token expires.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain to which the resource policy is attached.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

asset.documentation: The name of the requested asset.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the package version with the requested asset.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of the package version with the requested asset file.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version with the requested asset file. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package that contains the requested asset.

packageVersion.documentation: A string that contains the package version (for example, 3.5.2).

packageVersionRevision.documentation: The name of the package version revision that contains the requested asset.

repository.documentation: The repository that contains the package version with the requested asset.

asset.documentation: The binary file, or asset, that is downloaded.

assetName.documentation: The name of the asset that is downloaded.

packageVersion.documentation: A string that contains the package version (for example, 3.5.2).

packageVersionRevision.documentation: The name of the package version revision that contains the downloaded asset.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the package version with the requested readme file.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of the package version with the requested readme file.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version with the requested readme file. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package version that contains the requested readme file.

packageVersion.documentation: A string that contains the package version (for example, 3.5.2).

repository.documentation: The repository that contains the package with the requested readme file.

format.documentation: The format of the package with the requested readme file.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version with the requested readme file. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package that contains the returned readme file.

readme.documentation: The text of the returned readme file.

version.documentation: The version of the package with the requested readme file.

versionRevision.documentation: The current revision associated with the package version.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain that contains the repository. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: Returns which endpoint of a repository to return. A repository has one endpoint for each package format.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository.

repositoryEndpoint.documentation: A string that specifies the URL of the returned endpoint.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain containing the repository whose associated resource policy is to be retrieved.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository whose associated resource policy is to be retrieved.

InternalServerException.documentation: The operation did not succeed because of an error that occurred inside CodeArtifact.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return per page.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.
The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository associated with the package version assets.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: The format of the package that contains the requested package version assets.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return per page.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version that contains the requested package version assets. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.

package.documentation: The name of the package that contains the requested package version assets.

packageVersion.documentation: A string that contains the package version (for example, 3.5.2).

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the package that contains the requested package version assets.

format.documentation: The format of the package that contains the requested package version assets.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version that contains the requested package version assets. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

nextToken.documentation: If there are additional results, this is the token for the next set of results.

package.documentation: The name of the package that contains the requested package version assets.

version.documentation: The version of the package associated with the requested assets.

versionRevision.documentation: The current revision associated with the package version.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the requested package version dependencies.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: The format of the package with the requested dependencies.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version with the requested dependencies. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.

package.documentation: The name of the package versions' package.

packageVersion.documentation: A string that contains the package version (for example, 3.5.2).

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the requested package version.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of the package that contains the returned dependencies.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version that contains the returned dependencies. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.

package.documentation: The name of the package that contains the returned package versions dependencies.

version.documentation: The version of the package that is specified in the request.

versionRevision.documentation: The current revision associated with the package version.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the requested package versions.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: The format of the returned package versions.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return per page.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package that contains the requested package versions. The package component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet packages do not contain a corresponding component, packages of those formats do not have a namespace.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.

originType.documentation: The originType used to filter package versions. Only package versions with the provided originType will be returned.

package.documentation: The name of the package for which you want to request package versions.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the requested package versions.

sortBy.documentation: How to sort the requested list of package versions.

status.documentation: A string that filters the requested package versions by status.

defaultDisplayVersion.documentation:
The default package version to display. This depends on the package format:

  • For Maven and PyPI packages, it's the most recently published package version.

  • For npm packages, it's the version referenced by the latest tag. If the latest tag is not set, it's the most recently published package version.

format.documentation: A format of the package.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package that contains the requested package versions. The package component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet packages do not contain a corresponding component, packages of those formats do not have a namespace.

nextToken.documentation: If there are additional results, this is the token for the next set of results.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the requested packages.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: The format used to filter requested packages. Only packages from the provided format will be returned.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return per page.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace used to filter requested packages. Only packages with the provided namespace will be returned. The package component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet packages do not contain a corresponding component, packages of those formats do not have a namespace.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.

packagePrefix.documentation: A prefix used to filter requested packages. Only packages with names that start with packagePrefix are returned.

publish.documentation: The value of the Publish package origin control restriction used to filter requested packages. Only packages with the provided restriction are returned. For more information, see PackageOriginRestrictions.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the requested packages.

upstream.documentation: The value of the Upstream package origin control restriction used to filter requested packages. Only packages with the provided restriction are returned. For more information, see PackageOriginRestrictions.

nextToken.documentation: If there are additional results, this is the token for the next set of results.

administratorAccount.documentation: Filter the list of repositories to only include those that are managed by the Amazon Web Services account ID.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the returned list of repositories.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return per page.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.

repositoryPrefix.documentation: A prefix used to filter returned repositories. Only repositories with names that start with repositoryPrefix are returned.

nextToken.documentation: If there are additional results, this is the token for the next set of results.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return per page.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results. Use the value returned in the previous response in the next request to retrieve the next set of results.

repositoryPrefix.documentation: A prefix used to filter returned repositories. Only repositories with names that start with repositoryPrefix are returned.

nextToken.documentation: If there are additional results, this is the token for the next set of results.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to get tags for.

tags.documentation: A list of tag key and value pairs associated with the specified resource.

dependencyType.documentation: The type of a package dependency. The possible values depend on the package type. Example types are compile, runtime, and test for Maven packages, and dev, prod, and optional for npm packages.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package that this package depends on. The package component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet packages do not contain a corresponding component, packages of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package that this package depends on.

versionRequirement.documentation: The required version, or version range, of the package that this package depends on. The version format is specific to the package type. For example, the following are possible valid required versions: 1.2.3, ^2.3.4, or 4.x.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of the package.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package. The package component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet packages do not contain a corresponding component, packages of those formats do not have a namespace.

originConfiguration.documentation: The package origin configuration for the package.

PackageOriginConfiguration.documentation: Details about the package origin configuration of a package.

restrictions.documentation: A PackageOriginRestrictions object that contains information about the upstream and publish package origin configuration for the package.

PackageOriginRestrictions.documentation: Details about the origin restrictions set on the package. The package origin restrictions determine how new versions of a package can be added to a specific repository.

publish.documentation: The package origin configuration that determines if new versions of the package can be published directly to the repository.

upstream.documentation: The package origin configuration that determines if new versions of the package can be added to the repository from an external connection or upstream source.

PackageSummary.documentation: Details about a package, including its format, namespace, and name. The ListPackages operation returns a list of PackageSummary objects.

format.documentation: The format of the package.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package. The package component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet packages do not contain a corresponding component, packages of those formats do not have a namespace.

originConfiguration.documentation: A PackageOriginConfiguration object that contains a PackageOriginRestrictions object that contains information about the upstream and publish package origin restrictions.

displayName.documentation: The name of the package that is displayed. The displayName varies depending on the package version's format. For example, if an npm package is named ui, is in the namespace vue, and has the format npm, then the displayName is @vue/ui.

format.documentation: The format of the package version.

homePage.documentation: The homepage associated with the package.

licenses.documentation: Information about licenses associated with the package version.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

origin.documentation: A PackageVersionOrigin object that contains information about how the package version was added to the repository.

packageName.documentation: The name of the requested package.

publishedTime.documentation: A timestamp that contains the date and time the package version was published.

revision.documentation: The revision of the package version.

sourceCodeRepository.documentation: The repository for the source code in the package version, or the source code used to build it.

status.documentation: A string that contains the status of the package version.

summary.documentation: A summary of the package version. The summary is extracted from the package. The information in and detail level of the summary depends on the package version's format.

errorCode.documentation:
The error code associated with the error. Valid error codes are:

  • ALREADY_EXISTS

  • MISMATCHED_REVISION

  • MISMATCHED_STATUS

  • NOT_ALLOWED

  • NOT_FOUND

  • SKIPPED

errorMessage.documentation: The error message associated with the error.

PackageVersionOrigin.documentation: Information about how a package version was added to a repository.

domainEntryPoint.documentation: A DomainEntryPoint object that contains information about from which repository or external connection the package version was added to the domain.

originType.documentation: Describes how the package version was originally added to the domain. An INTERNAL origin type means the package version was published directly to a repository in the domain. An EXTERNAL origin type means the package version was ingested from an external connection.

PackageVersionSummary.documentation: Details about a package version, including its status, version, and revision. The ListPackageVersions operation returns a list of PackageVersionSummary objects.

origin.documentation: A PackageVersionOrigin object that contains information about how the package version was added to the repository.

revision.documentation: The revision associated with a package version.

status.documentation: A string that contains the status of the package version. It can be one of the following:

domain.documentation: The name of the domain on which to set the resource policy.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

policyDocument.documentation: A valid displayable JSON Aspen policy string to be set as the access control resource policy on the provided domain.

policyRevision.documentation: The current revision of the resource policy to be set. This revision is used for optimistic locking, which prevents others from overwriting your changes to the domain's resource policy.

policy.documentation: The resource policy that was set after processing the request.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the package.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of the package to be updated.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package to be updated. The package component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet packages do not contain a corresponding component, packages of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package to be updated.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository that contains the package.

restrictions.documentation:
A PackageOriginRestrictions object that contains information about the upstream and publish package origin restrictions. The upstream restriction determines if new package versions can be ingested or retained from external connections or upstream repositories. The publish restriction determines if new package versions can be published directly to the repository.

You must include both the desired upstream and publish restrictions.

originConfiguration.documentation: A PackageOriginConfiguration object that describes the origin configuration set for the package. It contains a PackageOriginRestrictions object that describes how new versions of the package can be introduced to the repository.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain containing the repository to set the resource policy on.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

policyDocument.documentation: A valid displayable JSON Aspen policy string to be set as the access control resource policy on the provided repository.

policyRevision.documentation: Sets the revision of the resource policy that specifies permissions to access the repository. This revision is used for optimistic locking, which prevents others from overwriting your changes to the repository's resource policy.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository to set the resource policy on.

policy.documentation: The resource policy that was set after processing the request.

RepositoryDescription.documentation: The details of a repository stored in CodeArtifact. A CodeArtifact repository contains a set of package versions, each of which maps to a set of assets. Repositories are polyglot—a single repository can contain packages of any supported type. Each repository exposes endpoints for fetching and publishing packages using tools like the npm CLI, the Maven CLI (mvn), and pip. You can create up to 100 repositories per Amazon Web Services account.

administratorAccount.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that manages the repository.

arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the repository.

description.documentation: A text description of the repository.

domainName.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain that contains the repository. It does not include dashes or spaces.

externalConnections.documentation: An array of external connections associated with the repository.

upstreams.documentation: A list of upstream repositories to associate with the repository. The order of the upstream repositories in the list determines their priority order when CodeArtifact looks for a requested package version. For more information, see Working with upstream repositories.

RepositoryExternalConnectionInfo.documentation: Contains information about the external connection of a repository.

externalConnectionName.documentation: The name of the external connection associated with a repository.

packageFormat.documentation:
The package format associated with a repository's external connection. The valid package formats are:

  • npm: A Node Package Manager (npm) package.

  • pypi: A Python Package Index (PyPI) package.

  • maven: A Maven package that contains compiled code in a distributable format, such as a JAR file.

  • nuget: A NuGet package.

status.documentation: The status of the external connection of a repository. There is one valid value, Available.

RepositorySummary.documentation: Details about a repository, including its Amazon Resource Name (ARN), description, and domain information. The ListRepositories operation returns a list of RepositorySummary objects.

administratorAccount.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID that manages the repository.

domainName.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

ResourceNotFoundException.documentation: The operation did not succeed because the resource requested is not found in the service.

resourceType.documentation: The type of Amazon Web Services resource.

ResourcePolicy.documentation: An CodeArtifact resource policy that contains a resource ARN, document details, and a revision.

document.documentation: The resource policy formatted in JSON.

resourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the resource associated with the resource policy

revision.documentation: The current revision of the resource policy.

ServiceQuotaExceededException.documentation: The operation did not succeed because it would have exceeded a service limit for your account.

resourceType.documentation: The type of Amazon Web Services resource.

SuccessfulPackageVersionInfo.documentation: Contains the revision and status of a package version.

revision.documentation: The revision of a package version.

status.documentation: The status of a package version.

Tag.documentation: A tag is a key-value pair that can be used to manage, search for, or filter resources in CodeArtifact.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource that you want to add or update tags for.

tags.documentation: The tags you want to modify or add to the resource.

ThrottlingException.documentation: The operation did not succeed because too many requests are sent to the service.

retryAfterSeconds.documentation: The time period, in seconds, to wait before retrying the request.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource that you want to remove tags from.

tagKeys.documentation: The tag key for each tag that you want to remove from the resource.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain that contains the repository that contains the package versions with a status to be updated.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

expectedStatus.documentation: The package version’s expected status before it is updated. If expectedStatus is provided, the package version's status is updated only if its status at the time UpdatePackageVersionsStatus is called matches expectedStatus.

format.documentation: A format that specifies the type of the package with the statuses to update.

namespace.documentation:
The namespace of the package version to be updated. The package version component that specifies its namespace depends on its type. For example:

  • The namespace of a Maven package version is its groupId.

  • The namespace of an npm package version is its scope.

  • Python and NuGet package versions do not contain a corresponding component, package versions of those formats do not have a namespace.

package.documentation: The name of the package with the version statuses to update.

repository.documentation: The repository that contains the package versions with the status you want to update.

targetStatus.documentation: The status you want to change the package version status to.

versionRevisions.documentation: A map of package versions and package version revisions. The map key is the package version (for example, 3.5.2), and the map value is the package version revision.

versions.documentation: An array of strings that specify the versions of the package with the statuses to update.

failedVersions.documentation: A list of SuccessfulPackageVersionInfo objects, one for each package version with a status that successfully updated.

successfulVersions.documentation: A list of PackageVersionError objects, one for each package version with a status that failed to update.

domain.documentation: The name of the domain associated with the repository to update.

domainOwner.documentation: The 12-digit account number of the Amazon Web Services account that owns the domain. It does not include dashes or spaces.

repository.documentation: The name of the repository to update.

upstreams.documentation: A list of upstream repositories to associate with the repository. The order of the upstream repositories in the list determines their priority order when CodeArtifact looks for a requested package version. For more information, see Working with upstream repositories.

repository.documentation: The updated repository.

UpstreamRepository.documentation: Information about an upstream repository. A list of UpstreamRepository objects is an input parameter to CreateRepository and UpdateRepository.

repositoryName.documentation: The name of an upstream repository.
The name of an upstream repository.

ValidationException.documentation: The operation did not succeed because a parameter in the request was sent with an invalid value.
